reviews.review:
Best game ever made 

15/10

First off if your tired of FPS that are like COD, Battlefield, etc than Half-Life is the game for you
Pros:
-Very original story (It is told through dialogue, and your always in the First-Person).
-Excellent gameplay (HL's gameplay is a mixture of stealth at some sequences and all out guns blazing in others)
-All elements to me are original
-Cool protagonist
-Pretty awesome weapons
-Challenging enemies in well designed maps

Cons:
-Some minor glitches (like getting stuck on a wall which can be fixed by shooting your weapon) (This was all on my version, not sure if it will appear in yours)
-Clunky platforming sections (There will be some parts of the game where platforming is required, and even if it looks like you can make the jump, you slip sometimes of the ledge).
-No Half-Life 3

Overall 9/10
Half-Life is an excellent game, but some minor glitches and the platforming sections frustrated me a little.
Half-Life is a masterpiece and not only do a recommend Half-Life 1, but buy Half-Life 1 Anthology and The Orange Box for Gordon Freeman's journey in full

At it's time, this maybe this is the best game ever. 
But for now, eh....
It's kinda hard to say, because this is still quite a gem
There's still some great enemy placement, some places where we feel powerless, some people who you want to save, though they're only NPCs
Really, I have never played a game that could make me feel powerless, while at the same time I knew I'm not (Valve's level design is quite great for their first game)
But eh, the graphic's outdated, so is the sound
Though, as someone who knew this game is gonne be outdated, it doesn't really put me off

But Xen
That final level
It could have some rework
I'm just a casual gamer though, I'm sure people who worked hard enough pays off their sweat
But me? Nah, thanks Utub

All in all, it's still a good game, if you're a gamer who care about the graphics and sound

Arcydzieło!

Grafika jak na grę sprzed 17 lat jest bardzo dobra, zwłaszcza dzięki teksturom HD, które zostały dodane później. Muzyki przez większość rozgrywki nie ma. Od czasu do czasu się pojawia, są to elektroniczne rytmy, które idealnie pasują do klimatu science-fiction. Half-Life posiada ciekawą, aczkolwiek momentami słabo wyczuwalną fabułę. Przez całą grę idziemy przed siebie, nie bardzo wiedząc gdzie i dlaczego. W grze jest dużo rodzai przeciwników, od żołnierzy HECU do najbardziej dziwacznych kosmitów. Również nasz arsenał jest bardzo bogaty, oprócz standardowych broni mamy do dyspozycji eksperymentalną broń Black Mesy i technologie obcych. Choć większość czasu spędzamy przemierzając korytarze ośrodka badawczego, zabijając napotkanych Xenian i żołnierzy,  to czasami musimy rozwiązać zagadki czy wypróbować swoje parkourowe możliwości. Produkcja Valve dla niektórych może się wydać trudna i rzeczywiście tak jest. Wiele razy próbowałem przejść dany fragment gry tak, żeby stracić jak najmniej życia, energii i amunicji. Momentami jest to frustrujące, ale gdy nam się już uda, to satysfakcja wynagradza trudy. Mi udało się ukończyć grę w niecałe 15 godzin, co jest zadowalającym wynikiem, głównie dlatego, że czasami przemierzanie korytarzy robi się nudne. W każdym razie, polecam Half-Life każdemu miłośnikowi oldskulowych FPS'ów. To gra, w którą każdy powinien zagrać.

Very challenging. It's a great game but it's very hard. It seems like a game that's mostly directed towards people who like scares and hard puzzles, (plus shooters).

I do like the game, but it's a bit to challenging for me. I do like the aliens and the storyline, but I don't like the jump scares. I'd say 7/10. It's a great game! It just needs a bit of work.

Half-Life is one of the greatest pc games of all time. Prior to HL, most games required roaming around corridors in predetermined paths shooting monsters and grabbing keycards. People loved it (and still do). But then HL came out and totally took things to a whole new direction. FPS were not just simple gimmicky shooters, they had puzzles, platforming sections, multiple paths and smart enemies. HL did all of this when nobody else did and it was a step forward in gaming. That was then. 

Today, Half-Life has shown it's age quite a bit. The AI is less smart, and more just frustrating. The enemy respawns, which were once terrifying, are now just a grind. The graphics, which were years ahead at it's dawn, are definitely aged. Then there are bugs. Bugs galore now. You can get by without ever playing half-life and just go straight to it's sequel, (which is arguably more frustrating in areas). But doing so you would miss out. Because despite all of Half Life's frustrations, it still remains a fun and challenging experience. 

You should play Half-Life. More so, you should have played it 15 years ago.

This game is probably one of the greatest classiscs of all time! It's old school style sci-fi experience is something that is timelessly replayable. It was one of the first games to feature a 'duck jump' action that has always got me to try it in other FPS games. The epansion content that was later released made the game look great, and added some new features, and through this game's engine, other classics, such as Counter strike, and Team Fortress were born. And the AI in these games were great for their time. Looking back this game is one of the cornerstones of alot of FPS game ideas.

I bought this, like many people of my (relatively young) generation, on the heels of the utter joy I derived from Half-Life 2 and its Episodes.  I knew that the original would be different, but I was still struck by surprise.  This isn't a bad thing; kinda like expecting something to taste delicious, and it [i] does [/i]--but in a different way than you expected.  Where playing HL2 felt like a cool, robust, rich and yet pleasantly mild drink of milk or the like, this original is like a super-carbonated beverage, constantly assaulting your senses with little bubbles and bursts of stimulation, maintaining a certain overall heat and intensity.  It's also got a pretty good deal of caffeine or sugar or something like that, because it is [b] HIGH-OCTANE [/b].  It's got the feel that instantly lets you know it's still somewhere among the ranks of those classic, balls-to-the-walls, pure-twitch-reflex heart-pumpers that pioneered the FPS genre: there are headcrabs (much faster and deadlier than their fat, sluggish regular counterparts from Half-Life 2) around [b] [i] EVERY [/i] [/b] corner, in every vent and crevice, behind and atop many boxes; WAVES of deadly alien creatures teleport/spawn in around most areas--if, that is, these areas haven't already been hard-claimed by incredibly aggressive (AI-wise; no waiting it out behind a door frame like the Combine) Marines cleaning up the evidence of the catastrophe using mounted .50-cal and rocket-launching turrets, laser-tripmines and laser-activated robo-turrets, oh, MY!!  Not quite as much time to stop and smell the atmosphere as the sequel, ladies and gentlemen!

However, those happily familiar with Half-Life 2 can enjoy noticing a lot of the subtleties in this first game that point in the direction the second went: elements of immersive storytelling, atmosphere, background, answers to continuity nods you didn't even know were [i] there [/i] in Half-Life 2, and the evolution of the whole universe between the events of this and 2.  Inside jokes, origin stor(y/ies), and little things that would become elements of the next installment abound; Barney's beer-debt to Gordon, the strange speech of the G-Man, the original noises the vortigaunts made that helps the player put together [i] why [/i] they have that weird, hypnotic accent and cadence in the second game, and some illuminating facts that make their cryptic fortune-teller-ominous-type dialogue lines in HL2 a bit clearer.  There are some familiar monsters, like barnacles, headcrabs and zombies and vortigaunts, but [i] a bit [/i] different from those [b] you [/b], Half-Life 2-only newcomers to the series, have known.  Plus, a whole [i] [b] MENAGERIE [/b] [/i] of others that are at most only [i] hinted [/i] at in the sequel: Bullsquids, Houndeyes, Ichthyosaurs, and Gargantua, just off the top of my head.  Also, where HL2 only has 11 weapons at most, you get an arsenal of 14, with 5 pretty crazy weapons never encountered in the second game--plus one more that you only get to use on a vehicle (the buggy) for a few levels (Highway 17 and the next few).

Overall, a [b] LOT [/b] more intense, even [b] [i] harrowing [/i] [/b], but an amazing [strike] game [/strike] [b] EXPERIENCE [/b] in its own right, and certainly MORE than worth its current price.  Need I say any more?  Pick up Half-Life today!  Heck, pick up the whole 15-buck original pack! [b] [i] [u] WORTH IT AND MORE. [/u] [/i] [/b]
No, really.  [b] DO IT [/b].  It's [u] [i] REAAAALLLY good [/i] [/u] !!!eleventy-one!!

Just competed Half-Life again on hard mode, it was awesome finding out lots of clever tactics, or ways to deal with each section of the map. Remember to use your weapons wisely and don't be afraid to use your ammo, especially when you have plenty of it, look out for enemies or items which might be hiding. Half-Life runs at a butter smooth 60fps even on my low-end laptop, likely due to the retro late 1990s graphics, which still look very good for a 17 year old game. Great soundtrack, plus sound plays a role in navigating the environment, where enemies are and what they are doing can be figured out once you know what sounds different types of enemies produce, take cover if you hear a grenade being tossed,  have the right weapon loaded and ready if you hear an alien close by ect...

This is one of the defining early first person shooters. Dated now in terms of graphics and sheer complexity. You can, however, adjust the difficulty. It can also regularly scare you to death, and it has a nice blend of exploration, light puzzles, and action. It is also quite a long game with large environments to explore. You will die many times and will spend many hours playing this masterpiece. Sometimes you need stealth. Sometimes you need to run. Fast. Really fast. Sometimes you need to go very slowly. Sometimes going in guns blazing is the right move. Sometimes you need to pick off your enemies one at a time. Sometimes you need to figure things out and solve problems. These changes in gameplay along with the sheer length and story will make you want to play it again and again. This is the first game. There are many more set in this same world after it. If you want to play them, play this first. 

Some might think the story is cliched or been overdone, but it was not so back when it was originally released almost 20 years ago. It starts off with an accident at a top secret lab and throws you into a sci-fi world of monsters, secrets, and other dimensions. You need to keep on your toes and fight your way out. Piece by piece you uncover a massive secret and conspiracy bound to destroy every person's reality down to their core.

Everybody who likes video games and everyone who especially likes FPS needs to have this game. Outstanding story for an FPS.

A great classic and yet another must for all FPS lovers!

This game pretty much pioneered with many things later found in a lot of FPS: "mute" protagonist, lots of weapons (classic and futuristic/alien), big variety of enemies/bosses and levels (even for today's standards), a bit of mystery/horror and an engaging story, left open for a sequel.

After all those years and despite having been outdated by many modern games, it still holds up well today, you can see what made it great at the time!

The game's "man with a gun" (or crowbar), the scientist Gordon Freeman, also became quite an iconic protagonist, boosting the belief that "nerds can be cool too"!

Some influences seem to have been taken from Wolfenstein 3D/Original Doom, though in their turn the latter games's sequels seem to have taken influences from Half-Life, showing how important all those games were for the FPS genre.
The whole "protagonist in a robotic suit, fighting a variety of aliens and marines" plot, makes me think that Halo probably also got some influences from here.

The addition of the G-Man as an antagonist, who watches your progress as you march further and further in the game and only those who pay attention will notice, was also great!

Finally, if I had to name just a minor flaw that would be that I didn't find the music addictive enough, it seemed almost non-existent to me (Return to Castle Wolfenstein for example had a great soundtrack and totally immersed you in the game), but don't let this small factor drive you away from this gem of a game, you can't be considered a true FPS fan until you have played this!

Came out roughly sixteen years ago now. Revolutionized the FPS genre and how it handles story telling. Is it still worth playing? Fuck yes it is. The guns are loud, powerful and satisfying, the enemies are fun to fight, have decent AI and look really cool, the story is somewhat minimal but handled in a way that communicates sufficient information to the player and simultaneously doesn't interrupt the gameplay too much which lets the game keep a very fast pace and has a slight air of mysterious freakiness about it, and the level design is solid aside from some first-person platforming and most of Xen. Might be worth waiting for Black Mesa to be finished, but Half-Life 1 is still a pretty fun, excellently designed and tight game on it's own.

Sencillamente, uno de los mejores juegos de la historia.
半条命，一个看着根本不像恐怖游戏的恐怖游戏，玩了都要吓出半条命.
I personally prefer this to the awesome HL2, but all games in the series are pretty great. Half Life focuses on more cramped, dark areas with a more evident horror element added.

Visuals: 8/10
Gameplay: 9/10
Audio: 8/10
Plot: 9/10

Overall 9/10
